awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Heterogeneity and Structural Duration Dependence in Macroeconomics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by NSF awards 1559459 and 155922. The research team seeks to test models of duration dependence in macroeconomics. The work focuses directly on how to analyze duration data from labor markets, including the duration/length of spells of unemployment. Some workers experience long-term unemployment, while others who are also unemployed rapidly find new jobs.  Similarly, some people stay with the same employer for many years (a long duration on the job) while others switch to a new job after a short stay. The PIs want compare different models of the processes that lead to these durations. They want to build new and tractable models and also plan to estimate and test the models to see which model is best supported by the data. The research will help us understand the nature of long-term unemployment, and it will benefit the U.S. economy by giving us a better basis for predicting the effects of certain kinds of public policy (such as extending unemployment benefits) on the economy.

The team plans to examine the nature of duration dependence in existing reduced-form models, such as the proportional hazard and the accelerated failure times models with unobserved heterogeneity. They also devlop new structural models, including a stopping time model, to offer a more economic interpretation of duration data, while allowing for arbitrary unobserved heterogeneity. They plan to use large existing data sets on labor market outcomes and on prices in order to estimate and test these models. The research has the potential to be useful in a wide variety of applications, since duration models have been used to study many different economic phenomena, including the determinants of business investment, housing turnover, nominal price stickiness, and the purchase of consumer durables as well as others.

por.por_cntn:
Many economic outcomes exhibit duration dependence, so the likelihood of an event occurring today depends on the amount of time since the event last occurred. For example, a worker who has been unemployed for a long time is less likely to find a job than a worker who is newly unemployed. A price that has been constant for a long time is less likely to change than a price that a firm recently adjusted. During the course of this award, the PI and co-PIs have explored why duration dependence arises and what its macroeconomics consequences are.

There are two broad explanations for duration dependence. First, it may reflect something structural about what happens in a particular state. Firms prefer to hire a newly unemployed worker, rather than one who has been unemployed for a long time, and so the latter is less likely to find a job. Prices that have been fixed for a long time are more salient in consumers? minds and so firms find it more costly to change them. Second, it may reflect dynamic selection. Some workers have a much harder time finding a job and so are more likely to become long-term unemployed. Some prices are costlier to change and so are more likely to stay fixed for a long time. Thus duration is simply a signal of underlying time-invariant characteristics, some of which may be unobserved by an econometrician.

During the course of this project, the PI and co-PIs developed new economic and statistical techniques for distinguishing heterogeneity from structural duration dependence. In ?Decomposing Duration Dependence in a Stopping Time Model,? the PI and co-PIs proposed an economic model that allows for both explanations of duration dependence. Workers face continual shocks to both the benefit and cost of working. They decide optimally when to work, but face a fixed cost of either starting or stopping work, for example due to job search costs. This gives rise to a well-behaved probability of finding a job as a function of the duration of unemployment for an individual worker. The research recognizes that workers are different, and so allows for heterogeneity in the shock process facing workers and in the fixed costs. The PI and co-PIs show how to decompose heterogeneity from structural duration dependence using data spanning multiple unemployment spells for individual workers. They uncover substantial heterogeneity, including a large number of workers who face a risk of permanent unemployment following job loss. Such heterogeneity may have important implications for the design and impact of social insurance programs.

In ?Consistent Evidence on Duration Dependence of Price Changes,? the PI and co-PIs develop a novel approach to estimation of the mixed proportional hazard model, a standard statistical approach to decomposing duration dependence in economics and many other fields. The new approach uses linear generalized method of moments, and so is easy to implement. They use the approach to examine data on the frequency of price changes. Although they uncover substantial heterogeneity across products, they still conclude that for an individual product, prices are less likely to change if they have already been held constant for a longer time. They then embed this heterogeneity into a model of monetary policy. They find that an unexpected permanent increase in the growth rate of the money supply leads to a temporary reduction in the real wage, hours worked, and output. If instead heterogeneity explained all the observed duration dependence in the probability of changing prices, the same shock would have been expansionary.

The PI and co-PIs have also explored related issues in separate projects. In ?The Macroeconomics of Sticky Prices with Generalized Hazard Functions,? a co-PI develops techniques to identify and estimate the effect of heterogeneity and structural dependence on the size distribution, rather than the timing, of price changes. The decomposition between the structural shape of price changes and heterogeneity is motivated by the same concerns, and the research draws on the same technical contributions. In ?High Wage Workers Work for High Wage Firms,? the PI and a co-PI develop techniques to measure the extent of sorting between workers and firms. They find that high productivity workers are more likely to work at firms that also employ other high productivity workers. This has important implications for the drivers of wage dispersion across workers. Again, although the question asked is different, the methodology draws on results discovered in their exploration of duration dependence.
